required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on October 07, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

brief_summary.textblock: The aim of this study is to capture data, laboratory markers, and clinical outcomes of obstetric and neonatal outcomes in cases of COVID-19 during pregnancy in Cuyahoga County.

detailed_description.textblock:
A review of the 55 cases of obstetric COVID-19 cases world-wide demonstrate the following fetal complications of COVID-19: miscarriage (2%), intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR; 10%), pre-eclampsia, and pre-term birth (39%). In Wuhan, China, nine women who were COVID-19 positive were surveilled for vertical transmission and overall obstetric and early neonatal outcomes. Amniotic fluid, umbilical cord blood, and neonatal throat swabs were collected at the time of delivery, and breastmilk samples were collected after lactation commenced. There was no viral detection of COVID-19 demonstrated.2 However, two neonates in the United Kingdom have tested positively for COVID-19 after delivery from an infected mother. Most recently, antibodies were detected (IgM and IgG) in the serum of a neonate born via cesarean delivery to a known positive mother. Therefore, vertical transmission has not been completely ruled out.
Additionally, infection at varying times of pregnancy has not been well delineated or correlated to neonatal or maternal outcomes at time of delivery. Therefore, there is a need to continue surveying and documenting clinical findings in obstetric COVID-19 cases.
This study will follow pregnant women who are diagnosed during any point of their pregnancy with COVID-19. The aim will be to evaluate maternal and neonatal specimens for the presence of COVID-19 virus, immune and cellular response.

primary_outcome.description: Viral presence in any of the collected specimens

secondary_outcome.measure: Presence of antibodies to COVID-19 virus
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At time of delivery and 24 hours of life of the newborn
secondary_outcome.description: Antibodies detected in any of the collected specimens

other_outcome.measure: Immune responses to COVID-19 virus What is the Immune responses of a mother infected with COVID-19 and neonates? What is the Immune responses of a mother infected with COVID-19 and neonates? Immune response to COVID-19 virus
other_outcome.time_frame: At time of delivery and 24 hours of life of the newborn
other_outcome.description: Innate/Adaptive cell function and immune response

arm_group.description: Women who are tested for COVID-19 at the time of admission for labor and delivery and test negative

arm_group.arm_group_label: Pregnant women with a history of COVID-19 infection
arm_group.description: Women who are tested for COVID-19 at any point during their pregnancy, including at the time of admission for labor and delivery, and test positive

intervention.description: Testing of amniotic fluid, cord blood, amnion and chorion, umbilical cord, vaginal mucous, maternal and neonatal sera, neonatal throat swab, and breast milk.
intervention.arm_group_label: Pregnant women with a history of COVID-19 infection

biospec_descr.textblock: Maternal blood, neonatal blood, amniotic fluid, amnion, chorion, umbilical cord, vaginal secretion, cord blood, newborn throat swab, breastmilk

study_pop.textblock: Pregnant women who have been diagnosed with COVID-19 at any point of their pregnancy.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- COVID-19 infection at any time of the pregnancy, or presumed case by symptoms and direct contact with a positive case
- Pregnancy documented by ultrasound
Exclusion Criteria:
- COVID-19 infection before or after pregnancy
- Person under investigation, but not a presumed or known positive case

results_reference.citation: Dong L, Tian J, He S, Zhu C, Wang J, Liu C, Yang J. Possible Vertical Transmission of SARS-CoV-2 From an Infected Mother to Her Newborn. JAMA. 2020 May 12;323(18):1846-1848. doi: 10.1001/jama.2020.4621.

Chen H, Guo J, Wang C, Luo F, Yu X, Zhang W, Li J, Zhao D, Xu D, Gong Q, Liao J, Yang H, Hou W, Zhang Y. Clinical characteristics and intrauterine vertical transmission potential of COVID-19 infection in nine pregnant women: a retrospective review of medical records. Lancet. 2020 Mar 7;395(10226):809-815. doi: 10.1016/S0140-6736(20)30360-3. Epub 2020 Feb 12. Erratum in: Lancet. 2020 Mar 28;395(10229):1038. Lancet. 2020 Mar 28;395(10229):1038.
